title: Pilaf with Currants and Pine Nuts
ingredients: 3 cups chicken stock (or if you prefer, you may use 2 bouillon cubes)
instructions: In a large pan and over medium-high heat, fry the onion in the oil until it is soft and golden.  Add the toasted pine nuts and stir until well mixed.  Add the rice and stir until the rice is well coated with the oil.

Add the chicken stock and stir in the allspice, cinnamon, salt, pepper, and the currants.  Bring the liquid to a boil, then lower the heat to low and simmer, covered, for 20 minutes or all the liquid has been absorbed and the rice is tender.
Lastly, stir in the butter and serve hot.
remarks: This is a classic dish from the courtly kitchens of Constantinople; with origins in the Ottoman Empire.  It goes well with meat or chicken dishes. Remember that with rice the salt is added to the liquid the rice will absorb, so taste the liquid to insure the “saltiness” is to your liking.  One should never add salt to the rice after all the liquid has been absorbed and is fully cooked. Yield:  Serves 6. Source:  The New Book of Middle Eastern Food by Claudia Roden, published by Alfred A. Knopf, © 1968, 1972, 1985, 2000 by Claudia Roden, distributed by Random House, Inc., New York.
